Resolve the Mixed Consignment Origin Issue** - **Problem:** The **Alpine (R454B refrigerant)** may trigger **different origin rules** (e.g., if the refrigerant is sourced from outside the EU/UK, it could disqualify the entire shipment from preferential origin under UK-EU TCA). - **Solutions:** - **Option 1: Split the Shipment (Safest, but Costly)** - **Two separate customs entries** (one for Lyon, one for Alpine). - **Pros:** - Clear origin declaration for each model. - No risk of HMRC challenging the entire container. - **Cons:** - Higher freight/handling costs. - More complex logistics. - **How to Execute:** - Work with your freight forwarder to **pre-clear each shipment separately** (even if in the same container). - Ensure **separate commercial invoices, packing lists, and origin certificates** for each model. - **Option 2: Unify Origin Claim (Riskier, but Possible)** - **If both models are **substantially transformed** in France (e.g., final assembly, testing, certification), you may argue they share the same origin.** - **Key Steps:** 1. **Obtain a Binding Origin Information (BOI) ruling** from HMRC (takes ~30-60 days, but worth it for future shipments). 2. **Document the manufacturing process** to prove that: - The **R454B refrigerant** is **incorporated in France** (not just imported). - The **Alpineâ€™s core components** (compressor, coils, etc.) are **EU/UK-origin** (or sufficiently transformed). 3. **Use a single EUR.1 or UK-EU TCA origin declaration** for the entire shipment. - **Risk:** If HMRC disagrees, they can **reject the entire container**, leading to **delays, storage fees, and potential penalties**. - **Mitigation:** - **Pre-clear with HMRC** (via your freight forwarder) before shipping. - **Hold the container at a UK bonded warehouse** until clearance is confirmed. #### **C. Avoid Direct UK VAT & IOR Liability for the French Parent** - **Problem:** If you act as the **declarant**, your French parent becomes **jointly liable** for UK VAT, duties, and customs compliance. - **Solutions:** - **Option 1: Use a UK Fiscal Representative (Fastest, but Costly)** - A **UK VAT-registered fiscal representative** (e.g., a customs broker or tax agent) can **act as the IOR on your behalf**. - **Pros:** - Legally insulates your French parent from direct liability. - Handles VAT registration, filings, and payments. - **Cons:** - **Cost:** ~Â£1,000â€“Â£3,000 per shipment (depending on complexity). - **Requires a UK VAT number** (can be obtained in ~2â€“4 weeks). - **How to Execute:** - Engage a **UK-based customs broker** (e.g., Kuehne + Nagel, DHL Global Forwarding, or a specialist like **Customs Support**). - They will **file the import entry, pay VAT/duties, and reclaim them** (if applicable). - **Option 2: Set Up a UK VAT-Only Entity (Long-Term Solution)** - If this is the **first of many shipments**, consider: - **Registering a UK VAT number** (without a physical entity) via a **non-resident VAT registration**. - **Pros:** - Full control over VAT compliance. - Avoids fiscal representative fees. - **Cons:** - Takes **4â€“8 weeks** to set up. - Requires **UK bank account & tax filings**. - **How to Execute:** - Use a **UK tax advisor** (e.g., **Sable International, VAT IT, or a Big 4 firm**) to handle registration. - Appoint a **UK tax agent** to file returns. - **Option 3: Force the Buyer to Act as IOR (High-Risk, but Possible)** - **Leverage contract terms** to **require the buyer to act as IOR**. - **How?** - **Amend the purchase order** to state: > *"Buyer shall act as Importer of Record (IOR) for all shipments into the UK. Seller shall not be liable for UK VAT, duties, or customs compliance."* - **Threaten to withhold shipment** until they comply. - **Risk:** They may **walk away from the deal**â€”but if theyâ€™re demanding EXW, theyâ€™re already trying to shift liability. --- ### **2.
